focus_skills: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables

questions.question: Which expression is equivalent to <math><mrow><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>?
questions.explanation: Combine like terms: <math><mrow><mn>7</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></math>. The constant term remains, so the expression is <math><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Always combine like terms before simplifying expressions.

questions.question: If <math><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></math> and <math><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>, what is the value of <math><mrow><mn>3</mn><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi></mrow></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></math> and <math><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>: <math><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>48</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>52</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Remember to follow the order of operations (PEMDAS) and handle negative signs carefully when substituting values.

questions.question: A rectangular garden has a length of 12 meters and a width of 5 meters. What is its perimeter, in meters?
questions.explanation: Perimeter of a rectangle = <math><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>w</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>. So, <math><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>17</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>34</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Know the formulas for perimeter, area, and volume of common shapes. Perimeter is the distance around the shape.

questions.question: What is the solution to the equation <math><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>22</mn></mrow></math>?
questions.explanation: Add 8 to both sides: <math><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></mrow></math>. Divide both sides by 5: <math><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Isolate the variable by performing inverse operations on both sides of the equation.

questions.question: Which expression is equivalent to <math><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn></mrow></math>?
questions.explanation: This is a perfect square trinomial. The square root of <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> is <math><mi>x</mi></math>, and the square root of 25 is 5. The middle term is <math><mn>−10</mn><mi>x</mi></math>, which equals <math><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math> with a negative sign, so the factored form is <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recognize perfect square trinomials: <math><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>±</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: For the system of equations <math><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></math> and <math><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></math>, what is the <math><mi>y</mi></math>-coordinate of the solution?
questions.explanation: Set the equations equal: <math><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></math>. Solve: <math><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></math> → <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>. Substitute into <math><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></math>: <math><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When both equations are solved for y, set them equal to each other to find x, then substitute back to find y.

questions.question: A store is having a 30%-off sale. If the sale price of an item is $56, what was the original price?
questions.explanation: Let <math><mi>p</mi></math> be the original price. Sale price = <math><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>30</mn><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>70</mn><mi>p</mi></mrow></math>. So, <math><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>70</mn><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>56</mn></mrow></math>. Divide by 0.70: <math><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>56</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>70</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For percent increase/decrease problems, write an equation: Original price × (1 ± percent as decimal) = New price.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,250 50,70 290,250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M50 230 L70 230 L70 250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5'/><path d='M250 250 A 40 40 0 0 0 253 222' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='35' y='65' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='300' y='260' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='35' y='265' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='30' y='160' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>6</text><text x='170' y='270' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>8</text><text x='225' y='245' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>θ</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right triangle labeled ABC. Angle C (bottom left) is 90 degrees. Side AC (vertical) is length 6. Side BC (horizontal) is length 8. Angle θ is located at vertex B.
questions.question: In the right triangle shown, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. What is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo></math>?
questions.explanation: In a right triangle, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>Opposite</mi><mi>Adjacent</mi></mfrac></math>. Looking at angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>θ</mi></math> (at vertex B), the opposite side is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math> (length 6) and the adjacent side is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> (length 8). Therefore, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>tan</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>6</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='400' height='300' viewBox='0 0 400 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='400' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,250 50,70 290,250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M50 230 L70 230 L70 250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1.5'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='50' y2='70' stroke='red' stroke-width='3' /><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='290' y2='250' stroke='blue' stroke-width='3' /><text x='35' y='65' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='300' y='260' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='35' y='265' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='60' y='150' fill='red' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>Opposite (6)</text><text x='150' y='240' fill='blue' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>Adjacent (8)</text><text x='225' y='245' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>θ</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same right triangle with the vertical side (AC) highlighted in red and labeled 'Opposite', and the horizontal side (BC) highlighted in blue and labeled 'Adjacent'.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recall **SOH CAH TOA**: **T**angent = **O**pposite / **A**djacent. Always identify the sides relative to the specific angle in question.

questions.question: The graph of the function <math><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math> is a parabola. What is the <math><mi>x</mi></math>-coordinate of its vertex?
questions.explanation: For a quadratic in the form <math><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></math>, the x-coordinate of the vertex is <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>. Here, <math><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></math>. So, <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>4</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize the vertex formula: For <math><mrow><mi>a</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></mrow></math>, the vertex is at <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math>.

questions.question: What is the smallest integer that satisfies the inequality <math><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>></mo><mn>27</mn></mrow></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve the inequality: <math><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>></mo><mn>27</mn></mrow></math> → <math><mrow><mn>4</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>></mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></math> → <math><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>></mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>. The smallest integer greater than 5 is 6.
questions.score_improvement_tip: After solving the inequality, remember to answer the specific question (e.g., 'smallest integer', 'largest possible value').

questions.question: The expression <math><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> is equivalent to <math><mrow><mn>15</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>19</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Expand <math><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>: <math><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>k</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math>. Combine x-terms: <math><mrow><mo>(</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></math>. This must equal <math><mrow><mn>15</mn><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>19</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math>. Equate coefficients: For <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>: <math><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></math> → <math><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>. Check x-term: <math><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>25</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>19</mn></mrow></math>, which matches.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When expressions are equivalent for all x, their corresponding coefficients must be equal. Start by equating the coefficients of the highest power term.

questions.skill: One-variable data: distributions and measures of center and spread
questions.question: The mean of a set of 7 numbers is 12. If one number is removed and the mean becomes 13, what was the number removed?
questions.explanation: Let the sum of the original 7 numbers be <math><mi>S</mi></math>. Then <math><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>/</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></mrow></math>, so <math><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>84</mn></mrow></math>. Let the removed number be <math><mi>x</mi></math>. The new sum is <math><mrow><mi>S</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>84</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></math>, and the new mean is <math><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>84</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>/</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>13</mn></mrow></math>. Solve: <math><mrow><mn>84</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>78</mn></mrow></math> → <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the formula: Mean = Sum / Number of items. Changes in the sum directly affect the mean.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='300' height='250' viewBox='0 0 300 250' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='300' height='250' fill='white'/><circle cx='150' cy='125' r='80' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='150' y1='125' x2='230' y2='125' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='4'/><line x1='150' y1='125' x2='110' y2='55.7' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' stroke-dasharray='4'/><line x1='230' y1='125' x2='110' y2='55.7' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M230 125 A 80 80 0 0 0 110 55.7' stroke='red' stroke-width='3' fill='none' /><text x='110' y='50' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='240' y='130' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='150' y='145' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>O</text><text x='180' y='80' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='blue'>Chord = 9√3</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O. Points A and B lie on the circumference. The chord AB (straight line) is highlighted in blue with a length of 9 multiplied by the square root of 3. The minor arc AB is highlighted in red. The radii OA and OB are shown as dashed lines.
questions.question: Points <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi></math> lie on a circle with center <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi></math> and radius <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. If the length of the chord <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>9</mn><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt></math>, what is the length of the minor arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: To find the arc length, we first determine the central angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>θ</mi></math> using the chord length. Construct a triangle with sides <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>, and chord <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt></math>. Using the Law of Cosines: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><msup><mi>c</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>a</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mi>b</mi><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. Substituting values: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><msqrt><mn>3</mn></msqrt><msup><mo>)</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>9</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>9</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo></math>, which simplifies to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>243</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>162</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>162</mn><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. Solving for the angle, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>cos</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>θ</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></math>, so <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>120</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. The arc length is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mn>120</mn><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mo>×</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mn>18</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When given a chord length, form a triangle with the two radii. Use the Law of Cosines or split the triangle into two right triangles to find the central angle, then calculate the arc length.

questions.question: What is the positive solution to the equation <math><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>?
questions.explanation: Factor the quadratic: <math><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>5</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></math>. The solutions are <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></math> and <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>. The positive solution is 7.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For quadratics, first try factoring. Look for two numbers that multiply to c and add to b in <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi></math>.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='350' height='300' viewBox='0 0 350 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='350' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><line x1='50' y1='280' x2='50' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='20' y1='250' x2='330' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><text x='320' y='280' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>x</text><text x='20' y='30' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>y</text><line x1='10' y1='63' x2='290' y2='250' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2' /><circle cx='50' cy='90' r='5' fill='black' /><text x='60' y='90' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>(0, 4)</text><circle cx='170' cy='170' r='5' fill='red' /><text x='180' y='170' font-family='serif' font-size='14' fill='red'>(3, k)</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A coordinate plane showing a blue line passing through the y-intercept at (0, 4) and a second point labeled (3, k). The line slopes downwards from left to right.
questions.question: The line shown in the <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane has a slope of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math> and passes through the point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></math> and the point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>. What is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>k</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: We can use the slope formula <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mfrac></math>. Plugging in our points <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></math>, we get: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mfrac></math>. Simplifying gives <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>. Since the denominators are equal, the numerators must be equal: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>k</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, so <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='350' height='300' viewBox='0 0 350 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='350' height='300' fill='white'/><defs><marker id='arrow' markerWidth='10' markerHeight='10' refX='9' refY='3' orient='auto'><path d='M0,0 L0,6 L9,3 z' fill='black' /></marker></defs><line x1='50' y1='280' x2='50' y2='20' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='20' y1='250' x2='330' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' marker-end='url(#arrow)' /><line x1='10' y1='63' x2='290' y2='250' stroke='lightgray' stroke-width='2' /><path d='M50 90 L170 90 L170 170' fill='none' stroke='green' stroke-width='2' stroke-dasharray='5,5' /><text x='100' y='80' fill='green' font-size='12'>Run: +3</text><text x='180' y='130' fill='green' font-size='12'>Rise: -2</text><circle cx='50' cy='90' r='5' fill='black' /><text x='30' y='90' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>(0, 4)</text><circle cx='170' cy='170' r='5' fill='black' /><text x='180' y='170' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>(3, 2)</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The graph illustrates the 'rise over run' concept. A green dashed line moves 3 units to the right (Run) and 2 units down (Rise) from the point (0,4) to arrive at the point (3,2).
questions.score_improvement_tip: Slope is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mtext>Rise</mtext><mtext>Run</mtext></mfrac></math>. If the slope is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac></math>, for every 3 units you move to the right, you must move 2 units down.

questions.question: If <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></mrow></math> and <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></math>, what is the value of <math><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></math>?
questions.explanation: Square the first equation: <math><mrow><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>8</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>64</mn></mrow></math>. Substitute <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow></math>: <math><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>15</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>64</mn></mrow></math> → <math><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>30</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>64</mn></mrow></math> → <math><mrow><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>94</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use algebraic identities like <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> to relate given quantities.

questions.skill: Ratios, rates, proportional relationships, and units
questions.question: Working at a constant rate, 4 identical pumps can fill a pool in 6 hours. How many hours would it take 6 of these pumps to fill the same pool?
questions.explanation: If 4 pumps take 6 hours, then 1 pump would take <math><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow></math> hours (inverse relationship). Therefore, 6 pumps would take <math><mrow><mn>24</mn><mo>/</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></math> hours.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For work problems involving identical workers/machines, the total work is constant: (Number of workers) × (Time) is constant.

questions.question: If <math><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></math>, what is the value of <math><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>?
questions.explanation: Substitute <math><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow></math> into the function: <math><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>4</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>12</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Evaluating a function means substituting the given input value for every instance of the variable in the expression.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='350' height='300' viewBox='0 0 350 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='350' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,250 300,250 50,50' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='128' y2='188' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><rect x='50' y='230' width='20' height='20' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><text x='35' y='265' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='310' y='260' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='35' y='45' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='135' y='180' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>D</text><path d='M65 210 Q75 220 70 250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><text x='75' y='210' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>40°</text><path d='M90 250 Q85 240 78 228' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><text x='95' y='240' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>x°</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A right-angled triangle ABC with the right angle at B (bottom left). Side AB is horizontal and side BC is vertical. A line segment BD is drawn from B perpendicular to the hypotenuse AC. The angle at B is split into two parts: the upper part (angle DBC) is 40 degrees, and the lower part (angle ABD) is x degrees.
questions.question: In the figure, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is a right angle and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></math> is perpendicular to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. If <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>m</mi><mi>∠</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, what is the value of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>, the measure of <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: We are given that <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is a right angle (<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>). From the figure, we see that <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math> is composed of two adjacent angles: <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>D</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>∠</mi><mi>D</mi><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi></math>. Therefore, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>90</mn></math>. Solving for <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi></math>, we get <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>50</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='350' height='300' viewBox='0 0 350 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='350' height='300' fill='white'/><polygon points='50,250 300,250 50,50' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='50' y1='250' x2='128' y2='188' stroke='black' stroke-width='2' /><rect x='50' y='230' width='20' height='20' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='2' /><text x='35' y='265' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>B</text><text x='310' y='260' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>A</text><text x='35' y='45' font-family='serif' font-size='16'>C</text><text x='80' y='240' fill='red' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>Total = 90°</text><path d='M65 210 Q75 220 70 250' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><text x='75' y='210' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>40°</text><path d='M90 250 Q85 240 78 228' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1' /><text x='95' y='240' font-family='serif' font-size='14'>x = ?</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The same triangle with a red square at vertex B emphasizing that the entire corner is 90 degrees. This visual aid makes it clear that x and 40 are complementary parts of the right angle.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a right angle is split into two smaller angles, they are **complementary**, meaning they add up to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>90</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.

questions.skill: Systems of 2 linear equations in 2 variables
questions.question: If <math><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></math> and <math><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>a</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Solve the system. From the second equation, <math><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow></math>. Substitute into the first: <math><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>(</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></math> → <math><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>10</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></math> → <math><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow></math> → <math><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>. Then <math><mrow><mi>a</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For systems, substitution or elimination are reliable methods. Choose the method that seems simplest given the coefficients.
